abstracts.cdata!:
The audit differs from the
            Implementation Completion Report's (ICR) ratings
            regarding the Rural Primary Education Management Project, in
            that project outcomes are downgraded from satisfactory to
            unsatisfactory, and likewise regarding Bank and Borrower
            performance ratings; yet, sustainability is upgraded to
            likely, while institutional development impacts remain as
            modest. Conversely, on assessing the Basic Education Project
            (PROMEB), the audit concurs with the ICR's ratings of
            satisfactory outcomes, substantial institutional development
            impacts, likely sustainability, and satisfactory Bank and
            Borrower performances. Experience with the assessed
            projects, confirm a number of the Operations Evaluation
            Department - OED - lessons in the education sector: Despite
            considerable quality-oriented investments by both the
            assessed projects, progress in student performance has been
            limited, confirming that educational project inputs, and
            rising education budgets do not translate automatically into
            increased student performance; rather, to increase
            performance, teachers and students must use inputs
            effectively, maximizing the instructional time students are
            engaged in learning. While both assessed projects developed
            action plans, their implementation was limited. Such actions
            must be feasible within the budget, and human resources
            available, and, Government officials must also clearly
            perceive the need for plans, and the subsequent actions.
            Notwithstanding, the PROMEB and its follow-up project
            successfully involved the communities in the management of
            rural schools, which suggests that decentralization of
            school management to the community level, may mobilize local
            support for the schools, thus increasing pride in
            achievement by students, and teachers. However, although the
            achievement tests developed through PROMEB provided valuable
            monitoring information to the government, such outcomes were
            not widely disseminated, and its use was limited: to be
            valuable, however, the information must be disseminated
            widely at the school level if possible, and actions must be
            carried out based on the feedback it provides.
